2000 ''Looking for the Local'', an exhibition at the [[Adam Art Gallery]], [[Victoria University of Wellington]]. Co-designer and co-curator with Paul Walker.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Looking for the Local {{!}} Adam Art Gallery|url = http://www.adamartgallery.org.nz/past-exhibitions/looking-for-the-local/|website = www.adamartgallery.org.nz|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref>
2015 ''Portraits of Practice,'' [http://sydney.edu.au/architecture/about/tinsheds/gallery/ Tin Sheds Gallery], [[University of Sydney]]. Co-curator and co-designer with Naomi Stead, Maryam Gusheh, Gill Matthewson and Fiona Young.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Portraits of Practice: At Work in Architecture|url = http://www.indesignlive.com/articles/parlour-inc-portraits-of-practice-at-work-in-architecture|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref>
== Awards == Victorian Institute of Architects, Bates Smart Award for Architecture in the Media (2009) - for Architecture Australia's special issue on Indigenous Housing.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Justine Clark - Office of the Victorian Government Architect|url = http://www.ovga.vic.gov.au/victorian-design-review-panel/profile-page/15-profiles/26-justine-clark.html|website = www.ovga.vic.gov.au|accessdate = 2015-09-13|first = Kate|last = Mallyon|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151117021405/http://www.ovga.vic.gov.au/victorian-design-review-panel/profile-page/15-profiles/26-justine-clark.html|archivedate = 17 November 2015|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
Victorian Institute of Architects, Bates Smart Award for Architecture in the Media (2011) - for her contribution to architectural discourse through the architectural publication [http://architectureau.com/magazines/architecture-australia Architecture Australia]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Justine Clark - Office of the Victorian Government Architect|url = http://www.ovga.vic.gov.au/victorian-design-review-panel/profile-page/15-profiles/26-justine-clark.html|website = www.ovga.vic.gov.au|accessdate = 2015-09-13|first = Kate|last = Mallyon|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151117021405/http://www.ovga.vic.gov.au/victorian-design-review-panel/profile-page/15-profiles/26-justine-clark.html|archivedate = 17 November 2015|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
Victorian Institute of Architects, Bates Smart Award for Architecture in the Media (2013) - for her contribution to [http://archiparlour.org/about/ Parlour]<ref>{{Cite web|title = 2014 Bates Smart Award open|url = http://architectureau.com/articles/2014-bates-smart-award-for-architecture-in-the-media/|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref>
Munro Diversity Award (2014), with Gill Matthewson.<ref>{{Cite web|url =http://www.architecturewomen.org.nz/aw%E2%80%A2nz-awards-2014|title =Architecture + Women NZ, Architecture Awards 2014.|date =|accessdate =|website =|publisher =|last =|first =|deadurl =yes|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20151117101211/http://www.architecturewomen.org.nz/aw%E2%80%A2nz-awards-2014|archivedate =17 November 2015|df =dmy-all}}</ref>
Victorian Institute of Architects, Bates Smart Award for Architecture in the Media (2015) - for her contribution to the [http://archiparlour.org/parlour-guides/ Parlour Guides to Equitable Practice]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Parlour Equitable Practice Guidelines|url = http://architectureau.com/articles/equitable-practice-guidelines-for-comment/|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | name = Karel Dujardin | image = Karel dujardin zelfportret.jpg | caption = Self-portrait, 1662 | birth_name = Karel Dujardin | birth_date = 1622 | birth_place = [[Amsterdam]] | death_date = 1678 | death_place = [[Venice]] | nationality = [[Netherlands]] | field = [[Painting]] | movement = [[Dutch Golden Age painting]] }} '''Karel Dujardin''' (September 27, 1622{{spaced ndash}}November 20, 1678) was a [[Dutch Golden Age painter]]. Although he did a few portraits and a few [[history painting]]s of religious subjects, most of his work is small Italianate landscape scenes with animals and peasants, and other [[genre painting|genre scenes]]. Dujardin spent two extended periods, at the beginning and end of his career, in Italy, and most of his paintings and landscape etchings have an Italian or Italianate setting.
==Biography== Karel Dujardin was a Dutch painter and [[etcher]], born in [[Amsterdam]] in 1622. Typical of his landscape paintings is ''Farm Animals in the Shade of a Tree'' (1656; [[National Gallery]], London). He died in [[Venice]] in 1678.
After supposedly training with [[Nicolaes Berchem]],<ref>Bolton, Roy (2009) ''The Collectors: Old Master Paintings'', "Karel Dujardin: ''A Horseman Holding a Roemer of Wine with an Ostler Tending the Horses''", London, Sphinx Books. {{ISBN|978-1-907200-03-8}}.</ref> the young Dujardin went to [[Italy]], and joined the [[Bentvueghels]] group of painters in [[Rome]], among whom he was known as {{lang|it|"Barba di Becco"}}, "goat-beard", or ''Bokkebaart''.<ref name=Houbraken>{{Link language|nl}}<!--Middle Dutch--> [http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/houb005groo01_01/houb005groo01_01_0329.htm Karel de Jardyn biography] in ''De groote schouburgh der Nederlantsche konstschilders en schilderessen'' (1718) by [[Arnold Houbraken]], courtesy of the [[Digital library for Dutch literature]]</ref> Here he encountered his first artistic successes.
According to Houbraken, while in [[Lyon]] in France, he contracted considerable debts, and married his (older) landlady to free himself of them. He went with her to Amsterdam, where his pictures were valued very highly.<ref name=Houbraken /> In 1675, he returned to Rome, on an invitation from his friend Joan Reynst and was welcomed by his old friends and admirers. Renst and Dujardin went on a [[Grand Tour]] to other Italian cities, but when Reynst went back to Amsterdam, Dujardin remained in Italy, and gave him a message for his wife that he would follow soon.<ref name=Houbraken /> [[Image:Karel Dujardin - Les Charlatans italiens.jpg|thumb|left|Karel Dujardin, [[Commedia dell'Arte]] Show, dated 1657 (Louvre)]]
He travelled on to [[Venice]] but died there unexpectedly in 1678. According to Reynst, he had said: "why should I be in a hurry to go back? I am where I want to be".<ref name=Houbraken /> According to his friend [[Johannes Glauber]], who he had met previously in Rome, he was painting for a Dutch merchant in Venice when he suddenly became unwell. Though he seemed to recover, his stomach was ''too full'' and he died. Though he was a member of the [[Dutch Reformed Church]], he was laid to rest in the Catholic manner (wrapped in a white shroud) and was carried to his grave by his friends [[Govert van der Leeuw]] and Glauber.<ref name=Houbraken />
Among his pupils were Jacob II, son of [[Jacob van der Does]], [[Martinus Laeckman]], and [[Erick van den Weerelt]].<ref>[https://rkd.nl/en/explore/artists/24701 Karel Dujardin] in the [[RKD]]</ref>
==Collections== [[File:Karel Dujardin - Boy Blowing Soap Bubbles. Allegory on the Transitoriness and the Brevity of Life - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|Boy Blowing Soap Bubbles. ''Allegory on the Transitoriness and the [[wikt:brevity|Brevity]] of Life'']] Dujardin is represented in the following collections amongst others: Detroit Institute of Arts, Michigan; Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco; Fitzwilliam Museum at the University of Cambridge, UK; Hermitage Museum, Saint Petersburg, Russia; Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indiana; J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles; Louvre Museum, Paris; Mauritshuis Royal Picture Gallery, The Hague; Minneapolis Institute of Arts, Minnesota; National Gallery, London, UK; Norton Simon Museum, Pasadena, California; Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam; Art Gallery of Greater Victoria, British Columbia; Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, UK; Cleveland Museum of Art, Ohio; Crocker Art Museum, California; Dulwich Picture Gallery, London, UK; Harvard University Art Museums, Massachusetts; Hunterian Museum and Art Gallery, University of Glasgow, Scotland; Norton Museum of Art, West Palm Beach, Florida; Ringling Museum of Art, Florida; Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium; Smart Museum of Art at the University of Chicago; Szépmûvészeti Múzeum, Budapest; The Wallace Collection, London, UK; Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum, Madrid; Rhode Island School of Design, RI,.
== Dujardin's work == <gallery perrow="4 " widths="168" heights="168" caption="Karel Dujardin's paintings "> File:Karel Dujardin - Woman Milking a Red Cow.jpg|''Woman Milking a Red Cow'', oil on canvas. Image:Karel Dujardin 001.jpg|''The sick kid'' Image:dujardin-farm-animals-boy-herdswoman-NG826-fm.jpg|''Farm Animals in the Shade of a Tree'', 1656, London, National Gallery. Image:Karel Dujardin 002.jpg|''The Herding boy'' Image:Karel Dujardin 003.jpg|''Rest at an Italian inn'' Image:Hagar and Ishmael in the Wilderness.jpg|''[[Hagar (Bible)|Hagar]] and [[Ishmael]] in the Wilderness'' Image:DUJARDIN Karel St Paul Healing the Cripple at Lystra.jpg|St. [[Paul the Apostle|Paul]] healing the cripple at [[Lystra]] File:Karel Dujardin- Tobias and the angel.jpg| ''Tobias and the angel'' </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links==

'''Keypers''' are [[toy]]s in the shape of [[animal]]s that were designed with opening compartments for children to store small items in. They were made in the 1980s by [[Tonka]] Corp.
==Overview== The Keypers characters depict animals (including a [[snail]], [[ladybug]] and [[turtle]]) and have small compartments which are intended for children to hide things in. The large adult Keypers have special keys so you can lock and unlock the compartments they have located on them. The small baby Keypers have a slit in their backs so you can squeeze, open and then hide things inside. The Keypers also have small Finders for friends. The Finders help the Keypers find lost items.
===Styles=== Various styles of Keypers were made, with many color variations depending on which country it was released in. Other variations were that some had glitter and non glittery eyes, and the adult [[bear]] even has different names depending on the [[United States|US]] or [[United Kingdom|UK]] version.
==As a collectors' item== Some Keypers items are very rare and are now sought after by collectors or for [[nostalgia|nostalgic]] reasons. Some items can be found in [[thrift store]]s, on [[online auction]] websites like [[eBay]], and on 1980s toy-selling webpages.
[[Category:Tonka brands]] [[Category:1980s toys]] [[Category:Toy figurines]] [[Category:Toy animals]]

page.title: List of posthumous publications of Holocaust victims

revision.text:
{{see also|The Holocaust in popular culture#Literature}} {{citations needed|date=March 2014}}
This is a '''list of works by [[Holocaust]] victims, published after they died'''.
==Published in English or translated into English==
*[[Hélène Berr]] (1921–1945): ''The Journal of Hélène Berr'' *[[Miriam Chaszczewacki]] (1924–1942): ''Diary'' *[[Adam Czerniaków]] (1880–1942): ''The Warsaw Diary of Adam Czerniakow: Prelude to Doom'' *[[Helga Deen]] (1925–1943): ''Never to Forget: Diary and Letters of Helga Deen 1943'' (in Dutch and German) *[[Julius Feldman]] (1923–1943): ''The Krakow Diary of Julius Feldman'' *[[Sarah Fishkin]] (1924–1942?): ''Heaven and Earth: the Diary of Sarah Fishkin'' *[[Moshe Flinker]] (1926–1944): ''Young Moshe’s Diary: The Spiritual Torment of a Jewish Boy in Nazi Europe'' *[[Anne Frank]] (1929–1945): ''[[The Diary of a Young Girl]]'' *[[Petr Ginz]] (1928–1944): ''The Diary of Petr Ginz'' *[[Éva Heyman]] (1931–1944): ''The Diary of Éva Heyman'' *[[Etty Hillesum]] (1914–1943): ''An Interrupted Life: the Diaries of Etty Hillesum, 1941-1943'' *[[Chaim Aron Kaplan]] (1880–1942): ''Scroll of Agony: The Warsaw Diary of Chaim A. Kaplan'' *[[Elsa Katz]] (d.1944): ''A Theresienstadt Diary: Letters to Veruska'' *[[Aryeh Klonicki]] (1906–1943): ''The Diary of Adam's Father'' *[[Věra Kohnová]] (1929–1942): ''The Diary'' *[[Janusz Korczak]] (1878–1942): ''Ghetto Diary'' *[[Herman Kruk]] (1897–1944): ''[[The Last Days of the Jerusalem of Lithuania: Chronicles from the Vilna Ghetto and the Camps 1939-1944]]'' *[[Rutka Laskier]] (1929–1943): ''Rutka's Notebook'' *[[Abraham Lewin]] (1893–1943): ''A Cup of Tears: A Diary of the Warsaw Ghetto'' *[[Ruthka Lieblich]] (1926–1942?): ''Ruthka: a Diary of War'' *[[Rywka Lipszyc]] (1929–1945): ''The Diary of Rywka Lipszyc'' *[[Ruth Maier]] (1920–1942): ''Ruth Maier's Diary: A Young Girl's Life Under Nazism'' *[[Philip Mechanicus]] (1889–1944): ''Year of Fear: a Jewish Prisoner Waits for Auschwitz'' (also titled ''In Dépôt'' and ''Waiting for Death''). *[[Irène Némirovsky]] (1903–1942): ''[[Suite française (Irène Némirovsky)|Suite Française]]''; ''Fire in the Blood''; ''All Our Worldly Goods''; ''The Wine of Solitude'' *[[Egon Redlich]] (1916–1944): ''The Terezin Diary of Gonda Redlich'' *[[Oskar Rosenfeld]] (1884–1944): ''In the Beginning Was the Ghetto: Notebooks from Lodz'' *[[Dawid Rubinowicz]] (1927–1942): ''The Diary of Dawid Rubinowicz'' *[[Yitskhok Rudashevski]] (1927–1943): ''Diary of the Vilna Ghetto'' *[[Philip Slier]] (1923–1943): ''Hidden Letters'' *[[Dawid Sierakowiak]] (1924–1943): ''The Diary of Dawid Sierakowiak: Five Notebooks from the Lodz Ghetto'' *[[Jerzy Feliks Urman]] (1932–1943): ''I'm Not Even a Grownup: The Diary of Jerzy Feliks Urman'' *Béla Weichherz — ''In Her Father's Eyes: A Childhood Extinguished by the Holocaust''
==Published in other languages and not translated into English==
* [[Jacques Bielinski]]: ''Journal 1940–1942. Un journaliste juif à Paris sous l'Occupation''.<ref>http://www.persee.fr/doc/xxs_0294-1759_1993_num_38_1_2698_t1_0121_0000_1</ref> * [[Abram Cytryn]]: ''Les Cahiers d'Abram Cytryn. Récits du Ghetto de Lodz''.<ref>http://www.sudoc.abes.fr/DB=2.1//SRCH?IKT=12&TRM=024397148&COOKIE=U10178,Klecteurweb,I250,B341720009+,SY,NLECTEUR+WEBOPC,D2.1,E99f69370-3fa,A,H,R81.154.169.156,FY</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Redirect|Mythcon|the Mythicist Milwaukee event|Mythinformation Conference}} {{Infobox Convention | name = Mythopoeic Society | image = [[Image:TheMythopoeicSociety.png|230px]] | caption = | status = Active | genre = [[Inklings]] | venue = [[Michigan State University]] | location = [[East Lansing, Michigan]] | country = United States | first = {{start date and age|1967}} | organizer = Mythopoeic Society | filing = Non-profit | attendance = 100-200 | website = {{URL|http://www.mythsoc.org}} }}
The '''Mythopoeic Society''' ('''MythSoc''') is a non-profit organization devoted to the study of [[Mythopoeia|mythopoeic]] literature, particularly the works of [[J. R. R. Tolkien]], [[Charles Williams (UK writer)|Charles Williams]], and [[C. S. Lewis]], all members of [[The Inklings]], an informal group of writers who met weekly in C.S. Lewis’ rooms at [[Magdalen College, Oxford]], from the early 1930s through late 1949.
== History == The Mythopoeic Society was founded in 1967 by [[Glen H. GoodKnight]]. Originally composed of discussion groups based in the [[Los Angeles]] area, it expanded to include organized branches across North America; in 1972 it assimilated the Tolkien Society of America. Membership is open to those who read, study, or write in the genres of myth and fantasy.
== Publications == Three periodical publications are produced by the society: * ''Mythprint'' is a quarterly newsletter with notices of Society activity, book reviews and articles;<ref> [http://www.mythsoc.org/mythprint/mythprint-history.htm "Mythprint: History and Back Issues"] Mythopoeic Society. Retrieved 2017-01-06.</ref> Mythopoeic Society membership includes electronic Mythprint (PDF), also available in print format by subscription. * ''[[Mythlore]]'', edited by [[Janet Brennan Croft]], publishes peer-reviewed articles on mythic and fantastic works, available by subscription.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7LGmdAPdwDgC&pg=PA68&dq=Janet+Brennan+Croft&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Fe0SUIL2CfLc4QTdk4CADA&ved=0CF8Q6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Janet%20Brennan%20Croft&f=false |title=Die aktuelle Tolkienforschung im Überblick: Personen – Organisationen – Verlage – Werke |trans-title=A Survey of Research on Tolkien: People – Organisations – Publishers – Works |language=German |first=Frank |last=Weinreich |first2=Thomas |last2=Honegger |pages=63–89 |journal=Zeitschrift für Fantastikforschung |year=2011 |issue=2 }}</ref> * ''[[The Mythic Circle]]'' is a collection of original fiction and poetry, published yearly, available by subscription.
In addition to the periodicals, the society formed [http://www.mythsoc.org/press.htm The Mythopoeic Press] to publish material by and about writers of mythopoeic and fantastic literature, especially focused on The Inklings. Works published include out-of-print materials, collections of short articles and essays, and scholarly items.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mythopoeic Press|url=http://www.mythsoc.org/press.htm|publisher=Mythopoeic Society|accessdate=April 9, 2014}}</ref>
== Activities == The society sponsors local discussion groups throughout the United States and the ''Annual Mythopoeic Conference'', also known as ''Mythcon'', generally held on college or university campuses in various locations, primarily within the United States.<ref>[http://www.mythsoc.org/mythcon.htm Mythopoeic Conferences] Mythopoeic Society. Retrieved 2017-01-06.</ref> Mythcon XX was held in Vancouver, British Columbia, in 1989. Mythcon XXIII was held at Keble College, Oxford, England, in 1992 as part of ''The J.R.R. Tolkien Centenary Conference'', co-sponsored with [[The Tolkien Society]]. Likewise, Mythcon XXXVI in 2005 was held at Aston University, Birmingham, England, combined with ''Tolkien 2005 - 50 Years of The Lord of the Rings'', sponsored by The Tolkien Society.<ref>[http://www.mythsoc.org/mythcon/mythcon-history.htm History of Mythopoeic Conferences] Mythopoeic Society. Retrieved 2017-01-06.</ref>
== Mythopoeic Awards == {{main|Mythopoeic Awards}} Since 1971 the Mythopoeic Society has bestowed a series of [http://www.mythsoc.org/awards.htm annual awards] to outstanding works. In 1991 the literary award was broken into two categories: the ''Mythopoeic Fantasy Award for Adult Literature'' and the ''Mythopoeic Fantasy Award for Children’s Literature''.
The ''Mythopoeic Scholarship Award in Inklings Studies'' is given to books on J.R.R. Tolkien, C.S. Lewis, and/or Charles Williams that make significant contributions to Inklings scholarship. The ''Mythopoeic Scholarship Award in Myth and Fantasy Studies'' is given to scholarly books on other specific authors in the Inklings tradition, or to more general works on the genres of myth and fantasy. For the scholarship awards, books first published during the previous three years are eligible, including finalists for previous years.
==See also== {{Portal|Middle-earth}} * [[Mythopoeic literature]] * [[The Tolkien Society]] * [[Tolkien fandom]] * [[Science fiction studies]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.mythsoc.org}} * [https://www.wired.com/geekdad/2009/07/geek-stuff-to-do-mythcon-2009/ Article: Geek Stuff to Do Mythcon 2009 by Corrina Lawson July 7, 2009, Wired.com]
{{Fantasy fiction}}

{{multiple issues| {{weasel|date=July 2009}} {{refimprove|date=February 2017}} }} {{Infobox company | name = N.S. Bienstock, Inc. | type = [[Subsidiary]] | logo = Nsbienstocklogo.gif | foundation = [[New York, New York]], United States (1964) | location = [[New York, New York]] (United States) | key_people = Richard Leibner, Founder & President| industry = [[:Category:Talent and literary agencies|Talent and Literary Agencies]] | homepage = [http://www.nsbienstock.com Official Website] }}
'''N.S. Bienstock, Inc.''' is one of the largest and most powerful television [[talent agency|talent agencies]] in the United States, representing more than 600 television personalities.<ref name=power>[https://www.nytimes.com/2002/06/24/business/media-a-talent-stable-that-s-huge-in-tv-news-is-it-too-big.html?pagewanted=all], accessed 02-04-2009</ref> Consistently ranked among the Top 10 of TV's most powerful,<ref name=Top10>[http://nsbvideos.com/images/articles/TVWeek2009.jpg], accessed 02-04-2009</ref> the group represents clients ranging from [[Dan Rather]] and [[Chris Matthews]] to [[Anderson Cooper]] and [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]].<ref name=press>[http://www.nsbienstock.com/pg/jsp/general/press.jsp], accessed 02-04-2009</ref>
Bienstock is the largest specialized agency, with more assets devoted to news and reality-based programming than any others. [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] claims the company has a "virtual monopoly on the news biz's biggest stars"<ref name=history>[http://www.nsbienstock.com/g/bsadvantage/487.html], accessed 02-04-2009</ref> and the president of MSNBC told the New York Times that, ''They have a disproportionate share of America's news talent. [[United Talent Agency]] acquired N.S. Bienstock on 22nd Jan 2014."<ref name=power />
==History== The company began in the 1940s as the small, New York City life insurance business of Nate Bienstock, whose client list included a number of journalists, including [[Walter Cronkite]], [[Charles Collingwood (journalist)|Charles Collingwood]] and [[Eric Sevareid]]. He sold a policy to the author John Steinbeck, who had Richard Leibner's father, Sol, as an accountant. Mr. Bienstock invited Sol Leibner into his business in 1964 and eventually sold out to him.
At the time, TV news was taking off, and Mr. Bienstock's newspaper and news agency clients were in demand at the networks. They asked for his help as they negotiated their contracts. Richard Leibner—not long out of New York University's business school—took up that part of the business and built it.
His wife and partner, Carole Cooper, whom he met on a blind date in 1962 and married in 1964, left her career as a producer of commercials to join the firm and become an agent in 1976. The firm also includes their sons, Adam and Jonathan.<ref name=power /><ref name=fam>[http://www.observer.com/node/36439], accessed 02-04-2009</ref>
But Mr. Leibner is the face of the company, perhaps best known for beginning the trend of big news salaries in the 1980s by playing the networks against one another and getting big deals for Dan Rather and Diane Sawyer. (The two now make more than $7 million and $10 million, respectively.) In the process, he has been accused of transforming journalists into something closer to Hollywood celebrities.
The agency has been at the forefront of the broadcast news business since 1964, pioneering representation of on-air and off-air talent in syndication, cable, reality television, and talk radio over the last 40+ years. The group not only represents talent, but also pitches and packages some of the most popular programs on both television and radio.<ref name=history />
The [[Radio Television Digital News Association]] administers a fellowship for young professional journalists endowed by N.S. Bienstock.<ref>http://www.rtdna.org/content/fellowship_info#.UwY3tWJdW8A</ref>
In 2014 N.S. Bienstock was acquired by United Talent Agency.
== List of notable present and past clients == {{colbegin}} * [[Dan Abrams]] * [[Stephanie Abrams]] * [[Glenn Beck]] * [[Ed Bradley]] * [[Margaret Brennan]] * [[Aaron Brown (journalist)|Aaron Brown]] * [[Campbell Brown]] * [[Juju Chang]] * [[Ti-Hua Chang]] * [[Jane Clayson]] * [[Lynnette Khalfani-Cox]] * [[Anderson Cooper]] * [[Katherine Creag]] * [[Phil Donahue]] * [[Howard Fineman]] * [[Jack Ford (news anchor)|Jack Ford]] * [[Michael Gargiulo (journalist)|Michael Gargiulo]] * [[Michael Gelman]] * [[David Gregory (journalist)|David Gregory]] * Kim Iverson * [[Gail Kasper]] * [[Steve Kroft]] * [[Lars Larson]] * [[Harvey Levin]] * [[Steve Levy]] * [[Tom Llamas]] * [[Chris Matthews]] * [[Jane Velez-Mitchell]] * [[Natalie Morales (journalist)|Natalie Morales]] * [[Norah O'Donnell]] * [[Pam Oliver]] * [[Byron Pitts]] * [[Dan Rather]] * [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] * [[Jeff Ranieri]] * [[John Roberts]] * [[Robin Roberts (newscaster)|Robin Roberts]] * [[Thomas Roberts (news anchor)|Thomas Roberts]] * [[Andy Rooney]] * [[Shiba Russell]] * [[Melissa Russo]] * [[Marc Santia]] * [[Diane Sawyer]] * [[Bob Schieffer]] * [[Bob Simon]] * [[Alison Stewart]] * Tracie Strahan * [[John Stossel]] * [[David Ushery]] * Steve Villanueva * [[Paula Zahn]] {{colend}}

page.title: Nike Instructs the Boy in Heroic History

revision.text:
'''Onomastics''' or '''onomatology''' is the study of the [[etymology]], history, and use of [[proper name]]s.<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Onomastics?s=t "onomastics"]. ''[[Random House Webster's Unabridged Dictionary]]''.</ref>
==Overview== ''Onomastics'' originates from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] ὀνομαστικός (''onomastikós''), which translates to "of or belonging to naming",<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Do%29nomastiko%2Fs ὀνομαστικός], Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, ''A Greek-English Lexicon'', on Perseus project</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?search=onomastics&searchmode=none|title=Online Etymology Dictionary|work=etymonline.com|accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref> from ὄνομα (''ónoma'') meaning "name".<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Do%29%2Fnoma ὄνομα], Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, ''A Greek-English Lexicon'', on Perseus project</ref> [[toponymy|Toponymy or toponomastics]], the study of place names, is one of the principal branches of onomastics. [[Anthroponomastics]] is the study of personal names. Onomastics can be helpful in [[data mining]], with applications such as [[named-entity recognition]], or recognition of the origin of names.<ref>{{cite arXiv|eprint=1310.6311|title= Onomastics and Big Data Mining|last1= Carsenat|first1= Elian|class= cs.CY|year= 2013}}</ref> It has also been used in historical research to identify ethnic minorities within wider populations.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = How Criminal were the Irish? Bias in the Detection of London Currency Crime, 1797-1821|url = http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/03058034.2016.1270876|journal = The London Journal|date = 2017-02-09|doi = 10.1080/03058034.2016.1270876|first = Adam|last = Crymble|pages=1–17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = A Comparative Approach to Identifying the Irish in Long Eighteenth-Century London|url = http://researchprofiles.herts.ac.uk/portal/services/downloadRegister/8738332/Irish_Surnames_in_London_2014_repositoryVersion.pdf|journal = Historical Methods|date = 2015-07-26|doi = 10.1080/01615440.2015.1007194|first = Adam|last = Crymble|volume=48|pages=141–152}}</ref> [[Literary onomastics]] is the branch that researches the names in works of literature and other fiction.<ref>{{cite book|title= Names in Literature: Essays from Literary Onomastics Studies|last1= Alvarez-Altman|first1= Grace|last2=Burelbach|first2=Frederick M.|year= 1987}}</ref> An ''orthonym'' is the proper name of the object in question, the object of onomastic study.
==See also== * [[Ancient Greek personal names]] * [[Etymology]], the study of word origins * [[Extinction of surnames]] * [[Hydronym]] * [[Mononymous persons]] * [[Naming convention]] * [[Toponymy]] * [[-onym]], listing the technical kinds of names
; Organizations * [[American Name Society]] * [[English Place-Name Society]] * [[Guild of One-Name Studies]] * [[International Council of Onomastic Sciences]] * [[Society for Name Studies in Britain and Ireland]] * [[UNGEGN Toponymic Guidelines]] * [[United Nations Group of Experts on Geographical Names]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{wiktionary}} * {{dmoz|Science/Social_Sciences/Linguistics/Onomastics/}} * [http://www.lgpn.ox.ac.uk/ Lexicon of Greek Personal Names], a Major Research Project of the British Academy, Oxford, contains over 35,000 published Greek names. * [https://onomast.com/ Onomast.com], contains over 50,000 given names with the meanings and origins

{| class="infobox bordered" style="width: 25em; text-align: left; font-size: 95%;" |+ style="font-size: larger;" | '''Oxford University Society of Bibliophiles''' |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | [[File:OUSB Device.jpg|245px|center]] |- ! Founded | 1950 (restored 2008) |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | '''Society officers, [[Hilary Term]] 2016''' |-
|- ! Honorary President | [[Henry Woudhuysen]], [[Rector (academia)|Rector]], [[Oxford|Lincoln College]] |- ! Honorary Vice-President | Paul W Nash, [[Bodleian Library]] |- ! President | Daniel Fried, [[New College, Oxford|New College]] |- ! Vice-President | Elle Pfeffer, [[Worcester College, Oxford|Worcester]] |- ! Secretary | Simon Korneev, [[St Catherine's College, Oxford|St Catherine's]] |- ! Treasurer | Constanta Burlacu, [[Merton College, Oxford|Merton]] |- ! Senior Committee | Geri Della Rocca de Candal, Cristina Dondi, [[Colin Franklin (bibliographer)|Colin Franklin]], Giles Mandelbrote, Scott Mandelbrote, [[Richard Ovenden]], William Poole, Julia Walworth. |- | colspan="2" style="font-size: smaller;" | |}
The '''Oxford University Society of Bibliophiles''' is a [[book collecting]] and [[Bibliophilia|bibliophile]] club run by, and primarily for, students at [[Oxford University]]. It was founded in 1950 by a group of young bibliophiles headed by John Granger, Bent Juel-Jensen and R. John Rickett, and the first meeting was held in Hilary Term of 1951.<ref>Nash and Howes 2006, p. 11.</ref> For fifty years the Society held regular lectures, visits and other events during the University terms, and many of the leading [[Bibliography|bibliographers]], [[librarians]], book collectors, [[booksellers]] and other literary figures of the period spoke to the Society or hosted visits. Many of the Society's junior members went on to become prominent figures in the world of books, and some later served as senior members of the Society. One of the most influential members was [[John Hanbury Angus Sparrow|John Sparrow]], Warden of All Souls, who encouraged a love of books and manuscripts in a generation of students, and hosted a termly "Warden's Meeting"<ref>Davies et al. 1977.</ref> at which members were encouraged to bring items from their own libraries to pass round and say a few words about; the tradition of the "Warden's Meeting" continued after 1986, when the Warden himself was too ill to host the meetings and, indeed, after his death in 1992. Another of the Society's traditions was the quality of the termly programme cards, often produced by the leading printers and [[private presses]] of the age, including the [[Oxford University Press|Oxford]] and [[Cambridge University Press|Cambridge]] University Presses, the [[Rampant Lions Press]], the [[Samson Press]], the [[Fantasy Press (UK)|Fantasy Press]], the [[Kit-Cat Press]], [[Big Wheel Press]], the [[Perpetua Press]], the [[Incline Press]], the [[Whittington Press]], the [[Libanus Press]], the [[Rocket Press]], the [[Stanbrook Abbey]] Press and the [[Officina Bodoni|Stamperia Valdonega]].<ref>Nash and Howes 2006, plates 1-4 and pp. 25-180.</ref>
After a period of difficulties and disrupted activities in the last decade of the twentieth century, the Society closed in 2000, when interest among the students had declined so far that a junior committee could no longer be formed. However, due to the efforts of a new generation of Oxford students led by Geri Della Rocca de Candal, Enrico Emanuele Prodi and Matthew Cheung Salisbury, aided by Cristina Dondi, [[Richard Ovenden]] and a few surviving members of the former Society (notably [[Colin Franklin (writer and bibliographer)|Colin Franklin]] and Paul W. Nash), the Oxford University Society of Bibliophiles was refounded in [[Trinity term]] 2008 and became fully active in [[Michaelmas term]] in the same year. The first termcard for the new Society was printed by the Rampant Lions Press (and was among the last jobs printed by Sebastian Carter).
The Society's device, shown opposite, was designed by [[Michael Harvey (lettering artist)|Michael Harvey]].

{{Redirect|Power Up|other uses|Power up (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox organization | logo = POWERUP.png | logo_size = 180px | type = [[501(c)(3)]] [[non-profit organization]] | founded_date = 2000 | founder = K. Pearson Brown
Stacy Codikow
Amy Shomer {{cite journal|journal=The Advocate|date=27 Mar 2001|title=Power up!|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BmMEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA49&lpg=PA49&dq=K.+Pearson+Brown+founder+%22Power+up%22&source=bl&ots=VsJ2djU0tB&sig=RiknSaLTyQeAwnPtTxDIo13w-48&hl=en&sa=X&ei=9cENT8DMFISY8QOSi-WjBg&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=K.%20Pearson%20Brown%20founder%20%22Power%20up%22&f=false}} | location = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], [[United States|U.S.]] | origins = | key_people = Stacy Codikow, Executive director
Lisa Thrasher, President of Film Production & Distribution | area_served = | focus = [[Motion picture]]s | method = Funding, producing | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = Professional Organization of Women in Entertainment Reaching Up! | homepage =http://www.powerupfilms.org/ | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''POWER UP''' (the "'''P'''rofessional '''O'''rganization of '''W'''omen in '''E'''ntertainment '''R'''eaching Up") is an [[United States|American]] [[non-profit organization]] and film [[production company]] with the stated mission "to promote the visibility and integration of [[lesbian|gay women]] in entertainment, the arts, and all forms of media". It was founded in 2000 by [[K. Pearson Brown]], [[Stacy Codikow]] and [[Amy Shomer]].{{cite web |url=http://www.power-up.net/celebrity_guests_include.htm |title=Challenging Perception through Film, POWER UP |accessdate=2007-05-15 |work=POWER UP |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070427101417/http://www.power-up.net/celebrity_guests_include.htm |archivedate = 2007-04-27}} Its members include women and men, gay and [[heterosexual|straight]]. POWER UP provides funding and assistance to filmmakers, as well as producing its own films. After several [[short film]]s, its first [[feature film]] was the [[comedy film|comedy]] ''[[Itty Bitty Titty Committee]]'' directed by [[Jamie Babbit]].{{cite web |url=http://www.afterellen.com/people/2007/2/powerlesbians?page=0%2C1 |title=The Top 13 Power Lesbians in Entertainment in 2007 |last=Lo |first=Malinda |date=2007-02-27|work=AfterEllen.com |accessdate=2007-05-15}} In 2004, POWER UP was awarded the Leadership Award by the [[National Gay and Lesbian Task Force]]. In 2001 K. Pearson Brown, one of the founding members, brought a sexual harassment suit against another founding member, Stacey Codikow. Codikow counter-sued alleging that Brown had made sexual overtures towards her and accusing Brown of defamation. Codikow also demanded Brown's resignation on the grounds that she was bisexual, and Brown later resigned. Both suits were dropped in late 2002.{{cite news|last=Welkos|first=Robert W.|title=Sexual harassment suit roils lesbian industry group|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/nov/02/entertainment/et-newwelkos2|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=November 2, 2002}} {{cite journal|last=Maynard|first=Kevin|title=Case dismissed|journal=The Advocate|date=24 Dec 2002|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JGQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA17&lpg=PA17&dq=%22power+up%22+sexual+harassment+Brown+Codikow&source=bl&ots=aAN5uEfiQk&sig=kIHobKruXarxLuapVbMQPZTNvkQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=c8QNT9GQGZTo8QP8zOGbBg&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=%22power%20up%22%20sexual%20harassment%20Brown%20Codikow&f=false}}{{cite journal|last=Maynard|first=Kevin|title=She said, she said|journal=The Advocate|date=10 Dec 2002|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XGQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA27&lpg=PA27&dq=K.+Pearson+Brown+%22Power+up%22&source=bl&ots=GsnsEoq1p3&sig=6heflc-CcsWr0yXy_EGoZmpK3IA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HMENT8CLH5P08QPDy93pBQ&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=K.%20Pearson%20Brown%20%22Power%20up%22&f=false}} ==Films== * [[2001 in film|2001]]: ''[[Stuck (2001 film)|Stuck]]'' - [[Jamie Babbit]] * 2001: ''[[Chicken Night]]'' - [[Lisa Ginsburg]] * 2001: ''[[Breaking Up Really Sucks]]'' - [[Jennifer McGlone]] * [[2003 in film|2003]]: ''[[Give or Take an Inch]]'' - [[Lee Friedlander (film director)|Lee Friedlander]] * 2003: ''[[Fly Cherry]]'' - [[Jessica Sharzer]] * 2003: ''[[D.E.B.S. (2003 film)|D.E.B.S.]]'' - [[Angela Robinson]] * 2003: ''Intent'' - [[Mary Ann Marino]] * [[2004 in film|2004]]: ''[[Little Black Boot]]'' - [[Colette Burson]] * 2004: ''[[The Nearly Unadventurous Life of Zoe Cadwaulder]]'' - [[Buboo Kakati]] * 2004: ''[[Billy's Dad Is a Fudge-Packer]]'' - [[Jamie Donahue]] * [[2005 in film|2005]]: ''[[Promtroversy]]'' - [[Leanna Creel]] * 2005: ''[[Starcrossed (film)|Starcrossed]]'' - [[James Burkhammer]] * [[2007 in film|2007]]: ''[[Itty Bitty Titty Committee]]'' - [[Jamie Babbit]] * 2008: ''The Nitty Gritty Behind the Itty Bitty Titty Committee'' - Lisa Thrasher * 2014: ''[[Girltrash: All Night Long]]'' - Alexandra Kondracke ==See also== {{Portal|LGBT}} *[[List of LGBT-related organizations]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.powerupfilms.org/ Official site] *{{imdb company|0026662}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Power Up}} [[Category:Film production companies of the United States]] [[Category:Lesbian organizations in the United States]] [[Category:LGBT arts organizations]] [[Category:LGBT organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2000]] [[Category:Women's film organizations]] [[Category:501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations]]
